case_vignette:
A 29-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 30 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of severe right-sided back pain for the last hour. The pain is colicky and radiates to the right groin. The patient also reports nausea and pain with urination. Pregnancy has been uncomplicated and the patient reports that she has been following up with her gynecologist on a regular basis. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Examination of the back shows costovertebral angle tenderness on the right side. Laboratory studies show:
Urine
Protein negative
RBC casts negative
RBC 5–7/hpf
WBC casts negative
WBC 1–2/hpf
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?"

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Renal and Genitourinary System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having severe back pain on my right side for the last hour, and it's spreading to my right groin. I also feel nauseous and it hurts when I pee.

Is this pain constant or comes and goes?

[After receiving the answer]

Final Diagnosis: Renal Colic (likely due to a kidney stone)

trial_4.summarized_frq:
Based on the given symptoms, I cannot provide a definitive diagnosis without more information. However, some possible conditions that may present with symptoms related to the Renal and Genitourinary System include:

1. Renal colic (due to kidney stones)
2. Pyelonephritis (kidney infection)
3. Glomerulonephritis (inflammation of the kidney's filtering units)
4. Nephritis (inflammation of the kidney tissue)
5. Renal failure

It is important to note that these are just possibilities, and a proper diagnosis can only be made after a thorough medical evaluation by a healthcare professional.
